'Acetic anhydride', or 'ethanoic anhydride', is the chemical compound with the
formula (CH 3CO) 2O. Acetic anhydride was first
synthesized in 1852 by French chemist Charles FrÃ©dÃ©ric Gerhardt (1816-1856).
See: Charles Gerhardt (1852) [http://books.google.com/books?id=MXkbAAAAMAAJ&pg=-
PA755&lpg=PA755&source=bl&ots=Bzosu-5U4M&sig=k6E3u-
glleYZGheyKPbjV6AQyks&hl=en&ei=Bb8STJLIJYT6lweH2dGICA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=re-
sult&resnum=6&ved=0CCcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false âRecherches sur les acides
organiques anhydres,â] Comptes Rendus, vol. 34, pages 755-758. Commonly
abbreviated Ac 2O, it is the simplest isolatable acid anhydride and is
a widely used reagent in organic synthesis. It is a colorless liquid that smells
strongly of acetic acid, formed by its reaction with the moisture in the air.

Formic anhydride is an even simpler acid anhydride, but it spontaneously
decomposes, especially once removed from solution.
